My brain exploded

Imagine this. Two sets of pendulums. Set 1 swings in the same direction together. Set 2 swing in opposing directions due to storing and releasing energy in the spring. But the chain length of set 2 is at the correct length so that the oscillating frequency of both sets is the same.

Then take one pendulum from each set and pair them. Then interact with the shorter length pendulum. Shouldn't the length of the other pendulum's chain balance out the effect of the increased frequency due to the spring, forestalling a swap in roles?

Of course if the roles did swap you'd have a compounded effect from the relatively shorter chain on the one pendulum taking on the role of a opposing sprung pendulum.

Intuition says chaos would ensue, but the mathematics is beyond me.

I am remembering a game called "quantum chess," in which you play a regular chess game, except each piece can be multiplied to create a superposition. The superposition is then resolved when one of the possible pieces either captures or is captured, and a computer calculates the probabilities of that piece and decides where the piece actually is. Now I'm wondering how much more complicated it would be if the probabilities oscillated and each piece has different probable locations depending on how long you took.

This internal dynamic that leads to superposition is a really cool metaphor to use for social sciences!!

Superposition is a fancy name given for literally adding things together. Which those 'things' are just the result of various different conditions.

Like you take the sides of any kind of rectangle and convert them into vectors ( ay, bx, -ay, -bx) (where a and b are the sides of the rectangle and the x and y indicate the direction), and add them up aka their superposition you get 0.

Another way to explain superposition is with linear electrical circuits with multiple voltage sources. Solve the circuit with only 1 of the voltage source active and turn the others off (0V is a short circuit and can be replaced with a wire). Do this again with the other voltage sources. You can then find the full solution with all the sources on by adding up all the results.

Even if you run the risk of over generalizing and missing important pieces.
